text: wood team member tested positive for covid-19 while working from home a wood team member experienced mild signs and symptoms associated with covid 19 and was seen and tested by a primary health care provider. the employee received a positive test result.  team member, reported to hssesome recommendations were sent to the employee by hsse

wood employee was stepping off a dump separator skid when he sprained his ankle. axiom was contacted and employee was taken to a medical facility for further evaluation. ie was diagnosed with a mid-grade sprain and first aid measures taken. migrated from legacy cairs incident #40179on november 29, 2018 at approximately 12:13 am on lease j bowen a6 (close to yorktown, texas), wood employee wasstepping off a dump separator skid when he sprained his ankle. axiom was contacted and employee was taken to a medical facility for further evaluation. iedid not suffer any fractures and was diagnosed with a mid-grade sprain. x-rays were conducted on the ie's ankle as well as a post incident drug/alcohol screening. medical professionalreleased ie back to work with no restrictions.first aid measures taken; which included over the counter medicine, ice and ace bandage. medical professional encouraged ie to begin using his foot and placing weight on it as soon as possible. area and account manager are overseeing the ie to make sure he is following allmedical advice. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

category: fall from or working at height issue, slips & trips
text: while exiting a crane, the operator lost contact with the ladder system and fell approximately five feet to grade.	 a team member (crane operator) was attempting to egress from the cab of a link-belt 130t rtc 80130 telescopic boom crane. the crane operator turned to face the crane and started to descend using the designed ladder system. when the injured person (ip) slipped/lost contact with the ladder system and fell to grade elevation.  the ip fell approximately 5’ landing in a sitting position.  nearby co-workers immediately responded to render aid and initiated the site emergency response protocols. the actual severity rating for the incident is classified as a b3 lost time injury to the ip.  the potential severity rating is a b4 currently due to the potential for serious injury/long term disability.  			 the ip was immediately evaluated, and local emergency responders activated. the ip was transported to via ambulance to the local hospital in wichita, ks. ip was  later admitted to hospital with diagnosed fracture. immediate notifications made. investigation team formed.

finger pinched between the pipe chamfer and the structure that was just below. on 15-02-2016, time 14:55 area 29, an helper was trying to put in position one pipe (8 inch). during this activity the pipe slightly slid and pinched his finger between the pipe chamfer and the structure that was just below him. the worker informed the supervisor on duty in order to go to the tra medical center (total first aid) which suggested to bring the worker to the nearest kaai 142 medical center for further examination, where he received appropriate care for his wounded finger. the following day the worker was back onsite to the normal working activity. the worker immediately informed the supervisor on duty, they went to the medical center in order to receive appropriate care for his wounded finger.

1 employee tested positive for covid 1 wood employee tested positive for covid19 while in quarantine for offshore assignment. personnel currently in quarantine station under ministry of health supervision

controlled venting of co2 improper filling required controlled venting of co2 by contractor. venting done at 5:30pm the same day when only two workers were onsight and with the north wind direction into a non-populated area (berkley pit), resulted in a safer operation.  co2 monitoring via personal air monitoring to confirm no risk to staff at the time of venting.

ponticelli-sices office worker twisted his right ankle  a ponticelli-sices office worker stepped over a small scaffold platform at the contractor village, mistepped and twisted his right ankle.  worker went to contractor clinic for checkup

proceeded to turn right across 2 way traffic system when a vehicle impacted my drivers off side door and wing at approx. 07:35 i proceeded along b7006 bathgate road to enter a&j grahams farm. this is the correct access to the ili dig site entrance. when suddenly a vauxhall astra travelling at speed impacted my right side of the  amecfw 4x4 commercial vehicle causing extensive damage to the drivers door, right wing and multiple damage to the third parties vehicle. no injuries where sustained.  vehicles made safe and removed from road side. all parties checked for injuries ( non located ) amecfw driver drugs and alcohol tested with in 2 hours of impact. test proof ( negative ). witness statements taken and await photo evidence. both vehicles recovered by 14:00hrs. police informed but did not attend incident due to no injuries or impact to public. ( reference number is  0566 )

a wood employee was in monitoring pre-embark to ppm1, performed the covid-19 test and the result was positive. a wood employee was in monitoring pre-embark to ppm1, performed the covid-19 test and the result was positive. the ip is asymptomatic. the employee is asymptomatic. the ip received guidance from the nursing technician regarding the necessary care and will be sent home for quarantine period.

team member stepped incorrectly while walking resulting in ankle discomfort. team member was walking to their work area in the unit's sub-basement when they stepped incorrectly with their right foot, resulting in ankle discomfort. incident potential rated an b-2 due to the potential of restrictionof work or requiring additional medical treatment for soft tissue injury. injured employee immediately reported to their supervisor and hssea department. soft tissue protocol administered. ie returned to work with (no restrictions) instructions to follow up at the end of shift, followingshift, and if the condition worsens.

proactive drops sweep of e1713b column took place finding high number of potential dropped objects. the e1713b column is 29 metres high and afw are acting as principal contractor on a project to carry out remediation. due to the nature of the project, a specific dropped object prevention plan was established and has been implemented. prior to site establishment, the project team were "handed" the column and the planned cdm area from sabic op's. a drops sweep of the column and all of its gantry walkways was led by the afw construction team, along with the main project contractor hertel.  the sweep found an alarmingly high number of objects had been left on the gantry walkways on the column, across all levels. some of these items were clearly historical (photos attached), however most of the items related to a recent "pickling" process carried out by the op's/ims team on site to prepare for the remediation project. all work in relation to the column is controlled by the sabic op's permit system.   hertel stood down from the project until resolved;area secured, access to the column restricted;photos obtained;information passed to sabic project and olefins 6 plant senior management;

a tais employee was hauling a welding machine with a fork lift through building 31 taking it to the outside of building 33a. the welding ma a tais employee was hauling a welding machine with a fork lift through building 31 taking it to the outside of building 33a. the welding machine slipped off of the forks and fell over on the floor in front of the lift. no one was injured. there was damage to the welding machine. no plant property damage occurred. the employee picked the welder back up and continued to the outside. there was damage to the welding machine. no plant property damage occurred. the employee picked the welder back up and continued to the outside.

category: foot or leg injury, line strike, vehicle incident general
text: an equipment operator struck an overhead neutral line migrated from legacy cairs incident #34715at the end of the day while the crew was zaplocking 3" pipe on the oxy bennett ranch unit project, one of the operators went back behind the work to move a cat 308emini excavator. the employee was not tasked to move the excavator and chose to do so on his own accord without instruction. the crew vehicles were positioned in the row behind the zaplocking task being performed, and the excavator was behind the vehicles. instead of asking people to move their vehicles so he could stay on the row, he drove the excavator off the row and crossed under overhead powerlines that paralleled the row and struck the neutral line tearing it down. he did not use a spotter, or remove the strap and pipe clamp attached to the bucket making it necessary to keep the boom elevated to prevent dragging the strap and clamp. there were no personal injuries involved. management and oxy were contacted. they were able to identify the line owner as an excel energy line. the work was on the opposite side of the row from the powerlines minimizing any need to drive close to the power-lines, much lesscrossunder them. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

category: foot or leg injury, back injury
text: ip sustained lower back pain / strain upon rising from a bent position migrated from legacy cairs incident #39934fac - ip sustained lower back pain / strain upon rising from a bent position after tiding work area(sweeping floor). attended medic and was issued non-prescription medication (no time off/light duty at present). migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

bitumen paint contaminated standing water which was now present in the shallow excavations at b2 and d4. all concrete bases at each ohl tower are currently in the process of being coated with bitumen based paint. it was noted that at pads d4 and b2 some of this bitumen paint had contaminated standing water which was now present in the shallow excavations created to allow the painting to take place. the explanation for this from the construction team was that one painting team did not follow the instruction to leave a 300mm buffer between ground and bottom of painting level.  the painting teams have now been further instructed to follow the correct procedure, i.e. include a 300mm buffer, work only in dry weather and pump out any existing standing water. the contaminated water from the excavations will now be pumped into ibc containers. ibc containers and pumps will now be made available on each section where painting is being carried out as precautionary measure. all towers/bases painted will be checked for contamination.

a sub-contractor for elkhorn construction at the shell appalachia project in mansfield pennsylvania (23-she-16004) had an employee hurt his back today. migrated from legacy cairs incident #31111a sub-contractor for elkhorn construction at the shellappalachia project in mansfield pennsylvania (23-she-16004) had an employeehurt his back today. the employee was tasked with rigging and spotting whilebreaking tail string at a bore exit. as employee arrived at the start of shift(6:00am) he was walking down the row and had his legs sink into the mud.employee had to struggle to get himself unstuck. employee felt no discomfort atthis point. employee continued his task and 4 hours later felt a sharp pain tohis lower back while walking down the row. employee stated he has sustainedprevious injuries to this same location on his back. employee was taken to eras per sub-contractors policies. x-rays were negative at er and only ibuprofenwere administered before being discharged. follow up visit with chiropractorwas scheduled. employee visited chiropractor and it was determined employee was released to return to work. the injury was found to be pre-existing and not caused by the employee getting stuck in the mud. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

while reinstalling a cover to an electrical panel the employee was working on, he bumped the main breaker causing it to trip.  there was no arc and there were no injuries. migrated from legacy cairs incident #38162while reinstalling a cover to an electrical panel the employee was working on, he bumped the main breaker causing it to trip. an investigation was started to determine what systems were temporarily shutdown and power was then reinstated. the panel did not arc and there were no injuries. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

excavator p1995 had a hose fitting fail resulting in approximately 2l hydraulic oil going to soil.  whilst working at frow kp5, excavator p1995 had a hose fitting fail resulting in approximately 2l hydraulic oil going to soil contaminated material collected for disposal. maintenance to inspect the machine and repair

category: bites (animals or insects), hand or arm injury
text: bee landed on hand but sting avoided due to the use of ppe i.e. gloves during an inspection on a remediation system, i found a bee's nest. the use of ppe (long-sleeved clothing, gloves, glasses) made it possible to avoid stings from the swarm.  pasquale confirmed he was not stung but the bee did land on his hand.

worker stung by insect while walking to collect his tool bag. wood maintenance hvac crew member had finished a task of  working at the lpr98 location in lngp when ip was on the way to collect his tool bag he encountered a flying insect(wasp) and ip was stung by a wasp at ~1630hrs follow upip attended the isos medical facility, and managed as a first aid case by the treating doctor. there were no work restrictions placed and ip was cleared to return to work.

employee communicated a positive confirmation for covid-19  wood is identifying those who may have worked in proximity.  appropriate notifications have been completed. this is the second of five positive results for the 30th of september. wood is identifying those who may have worked in proximity.  appropriate notifications have been completed. this is the second of five positive results for the 30th of september.

there have been a few mice sightings around our joint venture office. concerns around potential for hantavirus. migrated from legacy cairs incident #34672there have been a few mice spottings around the jv office in the last couple weeks. pest control was in after the first mouse sighting and put bait stations around that part of the office (b31). subsequently, there were two additional mice spotted in b29 and additional bait stations were set up by pest control on tuesday, sep. 26. pest control looked at the bait stations that had been placed around and noticed that there had been minimal feeding at the bait stations, which is a good indicator of small population of mice. the office building has a large ground floor footprint with loading bays so there are a lot of access points for mice, unfortunately. we are proceeding with air quality testing for hantavirus as well as a monthly pest control contract to maintain the bait stations. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

category: lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury
text: fac - cut to hand from handrail mesh within platform stairs. migrated from legacy cairs incident #36199whilst ascending west staircase between m deck and skid deck the individual bumped his hand on some handrail in fill mesh that was protruding into the stair case due to it being heavily corroded.the individual later identified that bump on the handrail mesh had in fact cut the back of his hand. on identifying this the individual then reported to his supervisor and then visited the medic to have the cut seen to.due to the individual not being aware of when his last tetanus shot had been administered the medic gave him a tetanus as a precaution.it was recommended by the top side doctor to include anti-biotic as precaution.stairs were barriered off and protruding mesh was bent back in and taped up for a temporary fix. all other stairs with similar set up were checked and plan put in place to replace corroded metal mesh panel.follow up call: individual was contacted by hsse advisor (steven farquhar) on 3rd january 2018 to see how he was and how the injuryto the back of the hand was progressing. individual was doing fine and cut to hand was healing fine. it was explained that the cut was washed, cleaned with plaster applied before returning to the rest of his shift prior to his planned departure on the morning flight. it was asked about the anti-biotic supplied and the individual identified at the time that it was not required due to the tetanus but was informed to take with him on his return home. individual also stated that he had not taken any as he felt it was not required. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

while holding the new post plumb in the hole, the soil under his feet gave way and he slipped partially into the excavation. employee was assisting with a post refusal replacement. while holding the new post plumb in the hole, the soil under his feet gave way and he slipped partially into the excavation. the employee was wearing a pfas consisting of a full body harness and srl anchored to an adjacent post.                                      employee reported no injury. the superintendent over the work is looking at a different way to replace post refusals.

while making a left hand turn driver contacted another vehicle. migrated from legacy cairs incident #38241on 6/20/18 at approx. 10:00 am lowboy driver was attempting to make a left hand turn onto shehan rd. in centerville, oh. while turning in the intersection driver contacted the right front of a vehicle. no injuries occurred and damage was minimal. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

late report – no injury - mt crosby westbank wtp had been shut down due to low sodium hypochlorite storage and the inability to fill the only available storage tank (no.1). investigation completed. migrated from legacy cairs incident #35973mt crosby westbank wtp had been shut down due to low sodium hypochlorite storage and the inability to fill the only available storage tank (no.1). relevant information and corrective actions:relevant information:1. no.2 tank is currently offline and isolated for replacement works.2. the sodium hypochlorite fill point isolation valve was observed as being closed, locked and isolated by the tanker driver when he began the process of filling no.1 storage tank early this morning.3. operations were not aware that the fill point isolation valve had been closed and isolated. 4. no impacts to water quality or quantity have been reported.corrective actions:1. a mechanical tradesperson from asset maintenance was contacted immediately and requested to attend site to de-isolate the fill point isolation valve.2. the tanker load of sodium hypochlorite was diverted to holts hill storage.3. coogee chemicals returned several hours later and transferred a load of sodium hypochlorite into no.1 storage tank at westbank wtp (1140est).4. westbank wtp was restarted soon afterwards. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

kl office employee slipped and fell at the ablution area in the prayer room, level 19, naza tower. at about 3.30pm, one of kl office employee slipped and fell at the ablution area after taking his ablution at level 19 wood prayer room, naza tower. he was attended immediately by our first aider and was sent to a clinic at level 11 naza tower for further checkup. doctor confirmed that he got muscle sprain and treated him with pain killer. he was asked to rest at wood first aid room at level 18 and doctor confirmed that he could resume light duty for the day. 1. the injured person was treated by wood first aider at level 19, wood office, naza tower2. he was then sent to a clinic at level 11, naza tower for further checkup. doctor confirmed no serious injury, only muscle sprain.3. a notice was placed at the ablution area to warn user of potential slip and fall at the area4. a safety moment will be sent to all staff reminding of slip and fell hazard at ablution area

category: lifting or moving loads, line strike
text: vertically rigged pipe slipped through rigging and fell to ground below in the process of assessing his work area, a pipe fitter walked up to a vertically rigged 40’ long 2” carbon steel pipe.  the pipe was rigged vertically in the pipe chase with a single choke.  as the pipe fitter touched the pipe to check the tension on the chain fall, the pipe slipped through the rigging and fell to the ground level of the boiler (approximately 90’).  on the way down, it struck and damaged a 2” stainless steel instrument-air line, the supporting hangers, and a piece of handrail area secured with red barricadeinspected other pipes rigged in the pipe chasecalled for a job-wide safety stand down

a mechanical fitter became unwel after feeling a pain in his left arm. at approximately 12: 00pm a mechanical fitter was stood in the smoke shelter with other colleagues when he felt a pain in his left arm, the ip said he panicked which caused his chest to tighten. another mechanical fitter went and raised his concern with his supervisor who raised the alarm 2222 where the emergency services attended the area and carried out some diagnostics, the ip was given the all the clear.  the ip stated that he felt a pain in his left arm and thought the worst causing his chest to tighten and panic. the emergency services were called to the area.the ip was taken to the changing room to sit while he was examined by the on-site service.the ip was given the all clear and felt much better after sitting for a while.the ip was fit to return to work the ip will be accompanied on any jobs for the remaining of the day.

injured by slipping or swinging object held by injured worker on october 11, 2018, an employee was using a handheld, gasoline-powered cutoff saw to cut aluminum material for recycling. the saw kicked back and struck the employee's face, causing laceration and fracture injuries. the employee was hospitalized. the hard hat's face shield was not in place at the time of the incident.
fall on same level due to slipping  an employee was walking into work from the outside when they slipped and fell on the wet floor, resulting in a broken humerus.

contact with hot objects or substances employee #1 was shutting down the system where molten resin goes through a filter prior to being cooled and processed on the belt. the employee tried to clean the material from the filter using nitrogen. the o-ring on the filter failed, allowing hot molten resin to spray out. the employee moved away from the area thinking that the pressure was relieved from the filter. when he returned with another employee, more molten resin sprayed out, burning both employees.

text: other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee was installing transition duct on top of a unit when he fell 5 feet to the concrete below, breaking his leg.

category: foot or leg injury, slips & trips
text: fall onto or against object on same level, n.e.c. an employee was completing a fluid treatment process. the employee had just closed a 4-inch valve on a "t" manifold when he tripped and fell forward, striking the shin of his right leg against a valve handle and then landing on the ground. the employee's right leg sustained a spiral fracture requiring hospitalization and surgery.

entangled in other object or equipment an employee was using a steel rod to break up sugar lumps in a silo when the rod was pulled in by the silo's screw conveyor and the employee's right hand was caught in the rod handle, amputating the right pinky, ring, and middle fingers.

injured by slipping or swinging object held by other person an employee walked into the vicinity of a co-worker who was using a brush cutter when the brush cutter kicked back and came into contact with the employee, resulting in a laceration that required surgery.

category: foot or leg injury, lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general
text: struck by swinging or slipping object, other than handheld, n.e.c. on may 14, 2021, at approximately 8:30 a.m., an employee was performing sandblasting operations on the inside rear of a trailer. the trailer was secured to a fixture that allows the trailer to be rotated in order to access different parts of the trailer frame. the counterweight had not been added to the frame or fixture and when the employee began to rotate the trailer, the trailer swung down and collided with their left ankle. the employee was hospitalized for an acute displaced fracture of the left tibia and fibula.

fall on same level, n.e.c.  an employee was taking samples of paper to check quality before it was sent to the final roll. he was standing on paper on the ground and had taken his samples when the final roll moved to uptake the slack and pulled the paper from under him. he fell flat on his back and was hospitalized.
struck against moving part of machinery or equipment an employee cleaned out a saw while the blade was still turning and the saw blade struck his fingers.

category: back injury, general injury, fall from or working at height issue
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was on a ladder repairing a light fixture. the employee fell from the ladder, suffering broken shoulder blades, broken ribs, and a bulging lower-back vertebra.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was using a wrench to adjust a bolt on a conveyor belt when he came in contact with the geared conveyance system, which pulled the wrench away from his hand. his right middle finger was in a circular opening of the wrench handle. when the wrench pulled away, it amputated his fingertip.
struck by swinging part of powered vehicle an employee was getting equipment from a truck when the truck door closed on him, rupturing a disc in his back. he was hospitalized.
exposure to environmental heat an employee was having shortness of breath and difficulty breathing while delivering beverages to various locations. the employee was hospitalized for dehydration.
